entries: A hierophant lich doesn't require air, food, drink, or sleep.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The hierophant lich is a 9th-level spellcaster. Its spellcasting ability is Wisdom (spell save {@dc 17}, {@hit 9} to hit with spell attacks). The hierophant lich has the following cleric spells prepared:

monster.name: Pact Lich
languages: The languages it knew in life

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (3/Day)
entries: If the pact lich fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.

trait.name: One with Shadows
entries: As a bonus action when in an area of dim light or darkness, the pact lich can become {@condition invisible} until it moves or takes an action or reaction.

trait.name: Patron's Blessing
entries: When the pact lich reduces a target to 0 hp, the lich gains 25 temporary hp.

trait.name: Pact Rejuvenation
entries: If a fist-sized or larger diamond is within its lair, a destroyed pact lich usually gains a new body in {@dice 3d10} days, but its return to the Material Plane is ultimately dictated by its patron.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The pact lich makes four enhanced eldritch blast attacks.

action.name: Maddening Touch
entries: {@atk ms} {@hit 10} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}10 ({@damage 3d6}) necrotic damage. The target must succeed on a {@dc 18} Charisma saving throw or have vivid hallucinations for 1 minute. During this time, the target is {@condition blinded}, {@condition stunned}, and {@condition deafened}, sensing only the hallucinatory terrain and events. The hallucinations play on aspects of the creature's deepest fears. The target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

action.name: Enhanced Eldritch Blast
entries: {@atk rs} {@hit 10} to hit, range 300 ft., one target. {@h}10 ({@damage 1d10 + 5}) force damage. On a successful hit, the pact lich can push the target 10 feet away from it in a straight line.

action.name: Hurl Through Hell (1/Day)
entries: The pact lich targets one creature it can see within 60 feet of it. The target must make a {@dc 18} Wisdom saving throw. On a failure, the target disappears and is {@condition paralyzed} as it is hurtled through the nightmare landscape of the lower planes. At the end of the pact lich's next turn, the target returns to the space it previously occupied, or the nearest unoccupied space, and is no longer {@condition paralyzed}. If the target is not a fiend, it takes 55 ({@damage 10d10}) psychic damage when it returns. The target must succeed on another {@dc 18} Wisdom saving throw or be {@condition frightened} until the end of the lich's next turn as the target reels from its horrific experience.

legendary.name: At Will Spell
entries: The lich casts a spell it can cast at will.

legendary.name: Fiendish Resilience
entries: The pact lich chooses one damage type, gaining resistance to that damage type until it chooses a different one with this feature. Damage from magical weapons or silver weapons ignores this resistance.

legendary.name: Maddening Touch (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: The pact lich uses its Maddening Touch.

legendary.name: Eldritch Master (Costs 3 Actions, 1/Day)
entries: The lich entreats its patron for aid, regaining all expended spells.
{@i Despite its frail appearance, the rotting, fiendish creature commands considerable arcane power.}
The first pact lich was a warlock whose patron was a demon lord of undeath. In a moment of whimsy, the demon granted the warlock's petition to become a powerful undead.

entries.name: Soul Devourer
entries: A pact lich must feed souls to its patron weekly to retain its lich status. It does this by reducing a creature to 0 hp within 120 feet of a diamond. Diamonds act as conduits for pact liches to send souls to their patrons, but only fist-sized or larger diamonds will do. A lich that forgets or refuses to sacrifice souls begins to physically fall apart, enduring incredible pain.

entries.name: Rebirth by Patron's Mercy
entries: When a pact lich's body is destroyed, the will and mind of the lich drains from it and returns to its patron. The patron decides whether to keep the pact lich or allow it to return to the Material Plane. Patrons are fickle beings and may decide to keep the lich for weeks or even centuries as punishment for its failure or may choose to never allow the lich to return. If the lich is allowed to return to the Material Plane, its body reforms in its lair next to a diamond it has used to send souls to its patron. Because the destruction of such diamonds means the possibility of eternal death, a pact lich usually hides many of these diamonds within its lair.

entries.name: Undead Nature
entries: A pact lich does not require air, food, drink, or sleep.

entries.name: A Pact of a Different Color
entries: The pact lich represented here is based on the Fiend patron. Not all patrons, especially not those of good or neutral alignment, would allow their warlocks to take the steps needed to become a pact lich. Those who revel in undeath, however, take special glee in unleashing such a destructive force on the world and reaping the souls the pact lich harvests. If you want to bring a pact lich into play from a different patron, some changes should be considered. Damage resistances, immunities, and actions like Hurl Through Hell can all be changed to reflect a different pact, like resistance to all weapons not made with cold iron for a pact lich whose patron is one of the Fey Lords or Ladies or hurtling a creature through the kaleidoscopic unknown of the Elemental Planes for a pact lich whose patron is a Genie Lord.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The pact lich's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 18}, {@hit 10} to hit with spell attacks). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring only verbal components:

trait.name: Amorphous
entries: The living shade can move through a space as narrow as 1 inch wide without squeezing.

trait.name: Shadow Stealth
entries: While in dim light or darkness, the living shade can take the {@action Hide} action as a bonus action.

trait.name: Sunlight Sensitivity
entries: While in sunlight, the living shade has disadvantage on attack rolls, as well as on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on sight.

action.name: Shadow Touch
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}2 ({@damage 1d4}) cold damage.
{@i Shadows dance on the wall, cast by the flickering firelight. One of the shadows suddenly turns in defiance of the person who cast it, reaching its dark hand out from the wall.}

Bursts of magic sometimes unexpectedly infuse a person's shadow, giving rise to a creature known as a living shade. Though similar in many ways to the dreaded undead shadows, these creatures aren't undead. They are a type of fey spirit infused with the power of the Plane of Shadow.

entries.name: Conjured Servants
entries: Some spellcasters draw power from shadow magic to deliberately turn their own shadow into a servant and guardian. Created living shades serve much as any other standard familiar spirit. A masterless living shade feels incomplete without a physical being to "cast" it, and it might agree to serve as another spellcaster's familiar as long as it's treated well.

entries.name: Playful Mimics
entries: Not inherently malicious, living shades spend most of their time serving as their master's shadow, delighting in mirroring gestures and motion. Occasionally, they enjoy toying with unsuspecting viewers by moving out of sync with their master in small, deliberate ways. Even unbound living shades might spend much of their time playing the part of someone's shadow, "attaching" themselves to a random passerby. Living shades communicate through pantomime.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The living star has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Resize
entries: As a bonus action, the living star can change its size. This trait works like the enlarge/reduce spell, except it deals {@damage 2d4} extra damage when enlarged and {@damage 2d4} less damage when reduced.

trait.name: Starshine
entries: A creature that starts its turn within 30 feet of the living star must make a {@dc 19} Intelligence saving throw. On a failed save, the creature is {@condition blinded} for 1 minute. If a creature's saving throw is successful or the effect ends for it, the creature is immune to the living star's Starshine for the next 24 hours.

trait.name: Supernova
entries: When a living star dies, it erupts, and each creature within 30 feet of it must make a {@dc 19} Dexterity saving throw, taking 56 ({@damage 16d6}) radiant damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. A creature reduced to 0 hp by this damage dies.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The living star makes three starflare attacks. It can use its Silvered Ray in place of one starflare attack.

action.name: Starflare
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 13} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}20 ({@damage 3d8 + 7}) bludgeoning damage plus 14 ({@damage 4d6}) radiant damage.

action.name: Silvered Ray
entries: {@atk rs} {@hit 12} to hit, range 150 ft., one target. {@h}28 ({@damage 4d10 + 6}) radiant damage, and the target must succeed on a {@dc 19} Charisma saving throw or be {@condition stunned} until the end of its next turn.

{@i A huge, glowing figure of churning, crackling energy bobs curiously above the battle, watching two warriors attack each other with sword and spear. The battle comes to a swift end when the figure flares, and both warriors slump to the ground, senseless.}

entries.name: Born of the Sun.
entries: As the sun moves across the sky, it sheds smalls bits of itself. Most of these motes of solar energy die out within days, burning themselves to oblivion. But on rare occasions, these bits of star stuff last long enough to gain sentience. They become living stars.

entries.name: The Life of a Living Star
entries: Living stars begin as young and immature balls of energy. They roam the heavens, observing the worlds below them. Based on those observations and interactions, they take on personalities and represent larger themes and domains—not unlike gods. The living stars may even insert themselves into the mortal realm, gaining worshippers and interfering in the lives of the creatures of the world.

entries.name: Radiant Nature
entries: A living star doesn't require air, food, drink, or sleep.

trait.name: Sticky Tongues
entries: Given half an hour, the lou carcolh can extend its 6 sticky tongues up to 60 feet from itself. A creature who touches one of these tongues must succeed on a {@dc 13} Dexterity saving throw or be {@condition restrained} as it adheres to the tongue. The tongues can be attacked (AC 12, 10 hp), and any damage done to a tongue is also done to the lou carcolh. Killing a tongue ends the {@condition restrained} condition, and the lou carcolh can't use that tongue for for the next 24.

trait.name: Slime Trail (1/Day)
entries: For 1 minute, the lou carcolh leaves a slime trail behind it as it moves. The slime creates difficult terrain, and any creature walking through it must succeed on a {@dc 13} Dexterity ({@skill Acrobatics}) check or fall {@condition prone}. The slime remains effective for 1 hour.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}11 ({@damage 2d8 + 2}) piercing damage and 2 ({@damage 1d4}) poison damage and the target must succeed on a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition poisoned} until the end of its turn.

action.name: Spit Venom
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 4} to hit, range 30/120 ft., one target. {@h}16 ({@damage 3d10}) poison damage.

action.name: Sticky Tongue
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 60 ft., one target. {@h}The target is {@condition restrained} and the lou carcolh can't use the same sticky tongue on another target.

action.name: Reel
entries: The lou carcolh pulls in each creature of Large size or smaller who is {@condition restrained} by one of its sticky tongues. The creature is knocked {@condition prone} and dragged up to 30 feet towards the lou carcolh. If a creature is dragged within 5 feet of the lou carcolh, it can make one bite attack against the creature as a bonus action.
{@i A slimy green serpent with a hardened shell-like growth upon its back, the lou carcolh epitomizes the horror of both snake and snail. Its venomous maw features two needle-sharp fangs.}

entries.name: Trappers
entries: The lou carcolh's preferred means of capturing prey is laying an ambush with its many mouth appendages stretched great distances, entrapping creatures who touch or step on them. The appendages regrow daily, so it is never without a fresh set.

entries.name: Steeds to Dark Fey
entries: Some dark fey creatures tame and ride lou carcolh as steeds. Their surprising speed, climbing ability, and comfort in the water make them ideal for traversing dread wetlands and fetid forests.

trait.name: Echolocation
entries: The werebat can't use its blindsight while {@condition deafened}.

trait.name: Keen Hearing
entries: The werebat has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on hearing.

trait.name: Shapechanger
entries: The werebat can use its action to polymorph into a bat-humanoid hybrid or into a Medium-sized bat, or back into its true form, which is humanoid. Its statistics, other than its AC, are the same in each form with the exception that only its true and bat forms retain its flying speed. Any equipment it is wearing or carrying isn't transformed. It reverts to its true form if it dies.

trait.name: Sunlight Sensitivity
entries: While in sunlight, the werebat has disadvantage on attack rolls, as well as on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on sight.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: In humanoid form, the werebat makes two mace attacks. In hybrid form, it makes two attacks. one with its bite and one with its claws or mace.

action.name: Bite (Bat or Hybrid Form Only)
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 2d4 + 2}) piercing damage. If the target is a humanoid, it must succeed on a {@dc 14} Constitution saving throw or be cursed with werebat lycanthropy.

action.name: Claws (Hybrid Form Only)
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d6 + 2}) slashing damage.

action.name: Mace (Humanoid Form Only)
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d6 + 2}) bludgeoning damage.

{@i A lean, muscled humanoid covered in short, velvet-like fur crouches on the rooftop, its long, membranous wings drooping to the ground like the sleeves of a long robe. Its face bears little trace of anything humanoid with large, pointed ears, needle-like teeth, black eyes, flaring nostrils, and dark fur.}

entries.name: Night Hunters
entries: Werebats hunt by night, swooping down from the darkness on unsuspecting prey and leaving mutilated corpses behind, often partially exsanguinated. When hunting, a werebat often takes on the form of a hideous, human-sized bat with a wingspan the length of a horse.

entries.name: Idolatry or Isolation
entries: In cultures that worship bat deities, werebats are often seen as holy creatures. They may occupy clerical roles in such societies, though their tendency toward malevolence drives them to use such positions to seek greater power. Werebats living in less convenient circumstances seek out isolated lairs overlooking remote settlements, moving frequently when their gory presence draws too much attention.
Regardless of their circumstances, werebats usually have a swarm of bats at their command.

entries.name: Telltale Features
entries: Werebats in their humanoid form often display bat-like features; a flattened or upturned nose, tufts of dark hair topping pointed ears, or sharp teeth are common.

from: natural armor in hyena or hybrid form

trait.name: Keen Hearing and Smell
entries: The werehyena has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on hearing or smell.

trait.name: Shapechanger
entries: The werehyena can use its action to polymorph into a hyena-gnoll hybrid or into a hyena, or back into its true gnoll form. Its statistics, other than AC, are the same in each form. Any equipment it is wearing or carrying isn't transformed. It reverts to its true form if it dies.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The werehyena makes two attacks. one with its bite and one with its claws or scimitar.

action.name: Bite (Hyena or Hybrid Form Only)
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d8 + 3}) piercing damage. If the target is humanoid, it must succeed on a {@dc 12} Constitution saving throw or be cursed with werehyena lycanthropy.

action.name: Claws (Hybrid Form Only)
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5}击中，到达5英尺，一个目标。{@h}8 ({@damage 2d4 + 3})砍击伤害。

action.name: Scimitar (Gnoll or Hybrid Form Only)
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d8 + 3}) slashing damage.
{@i The hyena's form shifts into that of a gnoll and then to something in between. In all three forms, blood drips from its filthy muzzle.}

entries.name: A Blessed Curse
entries: Across worlds and in all their cultures, the gnolls have always revered the hyena. Those who suffer the curse of lycanthropy also exhibit it in the same way: the form of a werehyena. This is considered a rare and wonderful gift, as most gnolls who suffer this curse die the first time they change. Those who survive, however, are honored in their culture.

entries.name: A Demonic Affliction
entries: In truth, the lycanthropy that werehyenas suffer is a demonic possession. The souls of these creatures have been forfeited to a demon lord. Only gnolls are able to survive this intact. If they spread this disease to a non-gnoll, the victim survives until the first full moon, after which it dies and turns into a demon gnoll under the demon lord's sway. The only way to save the victim is to cure the disease before the first transformation.

entries.name: A Terrible Cure
entries: Normally a {@spell remove curse} removes lycanthropy from a victim, but slightly more stringent efforts are needed to cleanse a werehyena's bite. While the {@spell remove curse} spell is being cast, a demonic creature must be killed in the vicinity of the victim, and the victim must drink the demon's ichor. Only then is the lycanthropy removed permanently. Finding such a creature can be difficult and often means making deals with dark forces.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 2} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 2d4}) piercing damage.

action.name: Shriek {@recharge 4}
entries: All creatures within 60 feet of the mandrake that can hear it must succeed on a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw or take 5 ({@damage 2d4}) thunder damage. If a creature fails the saving throw by 5 or more, it is {@condition stunned} until the end of its next turn. If it fails by 10 or more, it falls {@condition unconscious}. An {@condition unconscious} creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, regaining consciousness on a success.
{@i A crown of lettuce-like leaves sprouts from the soil. The leaves twitch slightly, and a faint, muffled squealing can be heard from the ground.}

entries.name: Howl of Injustice
entries: Though some herbalists can breed mandrakes, a mandrake only blooms in the wild under grisly circumstances: when an innocent youth is wrongfully hanged for theft, and the youth's dying blood, spittle, sweat, or urine strikes the earth. The mandrake remains dormant for one year, after which time it grows into a thick, tuberous root that is shaped like a young humanoid sprouting a thick, leafy head of hair. If the root is pulled from the ground, it wails with such piercing fury that most common folk who hear it die instantly.

entries.name: Medicinal Marvel
entries: Were it not for its incredible medicinal properties, the mandrake would never be cultivated at all. If ground into a powder and brewed for a year and a day, the mandrake root becomes an elixir of health, which can cure all poisons and afflictions.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: A great mandrake makes two attacks with its bite. When its shriek is available, it can use the shriek in place of one bite attack.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 2d4 + 2}) piercing damage.

action.name: Shriek {@recharge 3}
entries: Each creature within 60 feet of the mandrake that can hear it must succeed on a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw or take 11 ({@damage 3d6}) thunder damage. If a creature fails the saving throw by 5 or more, it is {@condition stunned} until the end of its next turn. If it fails by 10 or more, it falls {@condition unconscious}. An {@condition unconscious} creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, regaining consciousness on a success.
{@i A crown of lettuce-like leaves sprouts from the soil. The leaves twitch slightly, and a faint, muffled squealing can be heard from the ground.}

entries.name: Howl of Injustice
entries: Though some herbalists can breed mandrakes, a mandrake only blooms in the wild under grisly circumstances: when an innocent youth is wrongfully hanged for theft, and the youth's dying blood, spittle, sweat, or urine strikes the earth. The mandrake remains dormant for one year, after which time it grows into a thick, tuberous root that is shaped like a young humanoid sprouting a thick, leafy head of hair. If the root is pulled from the ground, it wails with such piercing fury that most common folk who hear it die instantly.

entries.name: Medicinal Marvel
entries: Were it not for its incredible medicinal properties, the mandrake would never be cultivated at all. If ground into a powder and brewed for a year and a day, the mandrake root becomes an elixir of health, which can cure all poisons and afflictions.

entries.name: Great Mandrake
entries: As a magical plant, the mandrake sometimes takes on an unusual appearance if it grows to full flowering. In these cases, the plant becomes thorny and its powers grow substantially. In particular, it gains the power of speech and its shriek becomes far stronger.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The mandriano makes two swipe attacks.

action.name: Swipe
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}11 ({@damage 2d6 + 4}) slashing damage. If the target is Medium or smaller, it is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 14}). Until this grapple ends, the target is {@condition restrained}. It can grapple up to three creatures.

action.name: Consume the Spark
entries: The mandriano drains the essence of one {@condition grappled} target. The target must make a {@dc 14} Constitution saving throw, taking 13 ({@damage 4d6}) necrotic damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. The target's hp maximum is reduced by an amount equal to the necrotic damage taken, and the mandriano regains hp equal to that amount. The reduction lasts until the target finishes a long rest. The target dies if this effect reduces its hp maximum to 0. A humanoid slain in this way rises 24 hours later as a zombie or skeleton under the mandriano's control, unless the humanoid is restored to life or its body is destroyed. The mandriano can control up to twelve undead at one time.
{@i Despite its size, the twisted and gnarled tree-man moves precisely and quietly. It cloaks itself in a cape of darkness with only its pale face visible, lit by blue flame eyes.}

entries.name: Damned Fey
entries: Mandrianos are a perversion of treants grown from soil defiled by ritual sacrifice. Bound to shepherd the undead, they ceaselessly wander their territories, collecting and tending their mindless charges. Beneath their billowing cloaks, their bodies have the gray color of driftwood. A mandriano's cloak is stitched from leaves of darkness and blows apart as if struck by a gale when the mandriano dies.

entries.name: Never Alone
entries: Mandrianos work in pairs or small teams as they gather their flocks of undead and hunt for the living. They drain the essence of living creatures to feed themselves, their deceptively long arms allowing them to quickly snatch up prey.

trait.name: Siege Monster
entries: The ancient mandriano deals double damage to objects and structures.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The ancient mandriano makes two swipe attacks.

action.name: Swipe
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 15 ft., one target. {@h}15 ({@damage 3d6 + 5}) slashing damage. If the target is Medium or smaller, it is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 16}). Until this grapple ends, the target is {@condition restrained}. It can grapple up to three creatures.

action.name: Consume the Spark
entries: As the mandriano, except the target must make a {@dc 16} Constitution saving throw, taking 21 ({@damage 6d6}) necrotic damage on a failed save, or half as much on a succes.

action.name: Call the Dead (3/Day)
entries: The ancient mandriano animates one humanoid corpse within 60 feet. This works like the animate dead spell, except it only creates zombies and the zombies. The mandriano can control up to twenty zombies at one time.
{@i Despite its size, the twisted and gnarled tree-man moves precisely and quietly. It cloaks itself in a cape of darkness with only its pale face visible, lit by blue flame eyes.}

entries.name: Damned Fey
entries: Mandrianos are a perversion of treants grown from soil defiled by ritual sacrifice. Bound to shepherd the undead, they ceaselessly wander their territories, collecting and tending their mindless charges. Beneath their billowing cloaks, their bodies have the gray color of driftwood. A mandriano's cloak is stitched from leaves of darkness and blows apart as if struck by a gale when the mandriano dies.

entries.name: Never Alone
entries: Mandrianos work in pairs or small teams as they gather their flocks of undead and hunt for the living. They drain the essence of living creatures to feed themselves, their deceptively long arms allowing them to quickly snatch up prey.

monster.name: Mantik, Barbed King of the Manticores

trait.name: Cursed
entries: Mantik may not fly, levitate, or be polymorphed by any spell or effect.

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (2/Day)
entries: If Mantik fails a saving throw, he can choose to succeed instead.

trait.name: Magic Weapons
entries: Mantik's weapon attacks are magical.

trait.name: Merciless Ferocity
entries: Mantik has advantage on all opportunity attacks, and a creature reduced to 0 hp by his attacks has disadvantage on its first death saving throw.

trait.name: Penetrating Volley
entries: If Mantik moves at least 20 feet in a straight line, all tail spike attacks made this round have advantage. A creature struck by these tail spike attacks must succeed on a {@dc 16} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}.

trait.name: Tail Spike Regrowth
entries: Mantik has thirty-six tail spikes. Used spikes regrow when he finishes a long rest.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: Mantik makes three attacks. two with his claws and one with his bite or three with his tail spikes.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}13 ({@damage 2d8 + 4}) piercing damage.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8}击中，到达5英尺，一个目标。{@h}11 ({@damage 2d6 + 4})砍击伤害。

action.name: Tail Spike
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 6} to hit, range 100/200 ft., one target. {@h}11 ({@damage 2d8 + 2}) piercing damage and the creature must succeed on a {@dc 16} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition poisoned} until the end of its next turn. A creature {@condition poisoned} by the tail spike has its speed halved and can't take the {@action Dash} action.

action.name: Roar of the Barbed King {@recharge 5}
entries: Mantik unleashes an ground-shaking roar. Each creature within 60 feet who can hear him must succeed on a {@dc 14} Wisdom saving throw or be {@condition incapacitated} for {@dice 1d4} rounds.

legendary.name: Move
entries: Mantik moves up to his speed without provoking opportunity attacks.

legendary.name: Growl (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: Mantik lets loose a throaty growl. Each creature within 60 feet who can hear Mantik must succeed on a {@dc 14} Wisdom saving throw or be {@condition frightened} of him until the end of its next turn.

legendary.name: Tail Spike (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: Mantik makes a tail spike attack.

{@i Much larger than his kin, Mantik's scarred and wizened visage is punctuated by longsword-length teeth that grind and clatter together when he speaks. His coloration is direst crimson, and his black wings appear too withered for flight.}

Inside the sandblasted walls of a ruined castle, the king of the manticores roars decrees to the wind. Mantik, the oldest and most ferocious of his kind, sits atop the shattered throne of a long-forgotten kingdom. He is loved like a god by a loyal clan of kobolds, who bring the beast treasures and sacrifices.

entries.name: Withered Wings
entries: Mantik's wings have mysteriously shrunken into two withered appendages. A kobold shaman suggested the Barbed King has come under a curse of some sort. Mantik believes divine magic is the only way to restore his ability to fly, but he is too proud to learn prayer or engage in devotion. Whatever the reason for his withered wings, Mantik bitterly plots to cure his strange affliction.

entries.name: The Barbed
entries: The kobolds who worship Mantik refer to themselves as the Barbed. They scurry around the manticore's castle like servile rats, both enamored and terrified of their ruler.

entries.name: Covetous
entries: Mantik has a substantial hoard gathered in the ruined chambers under his castle. His manticores raid the infrequent trade caravans traveling the wastes, and several times a year he embarks on treasure hunting expeditions, stalking the many scavenger bands picking through lost battlefields. His throne room is filled with ancient carvings, fractured statues, old tapestries, and jewelry-all displayed on crumbling stone pedestals or awkwardly hung from pock‑marked walls. Mantik both loves and loathes his hoard; he yearns for a castle fit to hold his treasures.

entries.name: Mantik in Midgard
entries: In Midgard, Mantik dwells in a ruined castle deep in the Red Wastes that sprawl between the Dragon Empire and Khandiria. Surrounded by his motley army, Mantik lusts for a taste of the wealth kept in the Dragoncoil Mountains and in the cities of Khandiria, starting with Isquetta. His own treasury is filled with the spoils of his raids on caravans and drake lairs. He covets the three feathers of Azuran—magical sapphires carved into the shape of crane feathers—most of all. Mantik believes the jewels will restore his ability to fly.

trait.name: Pack Tactics
entries: The kobold has advantage on attack rolls against a creature if at least one of the kobold's allies is within 5 feet of the creature and the ally isn't {@condition incapacitated}.

trait.name: Sunlight Sensitivity
entries: While in sunlight, the kobold has disadvantage on attack rolls, as well as on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on sight.

action.name: Barbed Slash
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 2d4 + 2}) slashing damage and 3 ({@damage 1d6}) poison damage. The target must succeed on a {@dc 12} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition poisoned} until the end of its next turn.

action.name: Javelin
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 4} to hit, range 30/120 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d6 + 2}) piercing damage.
{@i A brawny looking kobold brandishes a manticore spike driven through its scaled hand.}

entries.name: Leaders
entries: The barbed are physically stronger than their brethren and bear the scars of living close to manticores. They are devoted to Mantik and believe he is a divine being who will lead them to victory over the drakes of the waste and the dragons of the mountains.

entries.name: Marked
entries: The barbed are known by the large tail spike (from Mantik himself) driven through their wrist and hand. They are immune to the poison that still seeps from the spike.

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (3/Day)
entries: If the Master fails a saving throw, he can choose to succeed instead.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The Master has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Master of Fiends
entries: Fiends summoned by the Master's Summon Fiend share a telepathic link with him, are under his control, and can't summon other demons or devils. A fiend remains until it or the Master dies or until the Master dismisses it as a bonus action. The total CR of the fiends under the Master's control can't exceed 16, otherwise the Master can summon any number or combination of fiends. Any fiends the Master attempts to summon in excess of this limit aren't summoned.

action.name: Master's Knife
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 10} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}11 ({@damage 2d6 + 4}) slashing damage plus 14 ({@damage 4d6}) fire damage.

action.name: Summon Fiend {@recharge 6}
entries: The Master summons {@dice 2d4} {@creature wind demon|ccodex|wind demons} (see page 93), {@dice 1d4} {@creature wind's harp|ccodex|wind's harp devils} (see page 105), {@dice 1d2} {@creature vrock|mm|vrocks}, {@dice 1d2} {@creature chain devil|mm|chain devils}, or 1 {@creature fulad-zereh|ccodex} (see page 85) with no chance of failure. A summoned fiend appears in an unoccupied space within 60 feet of the Master and acts immediately and on the Master's initiative.

legendary.name: Detect
entries: The Master makes a Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check.

legendary.name: Teleport (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: The Master magically teleports, along with any equipment he is wearing or carrying, up to 120 feet to an unoccupied space he can see.

legendary.name: Cast a Spell (Costs 3 Actions)
entries: The Master casts a spell from his list of prepared spells, using a spell slot as normal.

{@i With a dark beard and fiery eyes, the master of Demon Mountain has long been a figure of terror to those who live within sight of his castle. Some say he is the dark, twisted son of Baba Yaga and an unnamed lord of the Abyss. Demons, certainly, bow and speak politely to him, and the least of them jump to his command.}

entries.name: Father of Fiends
entries: The Master of Demon Mountain is a creature of lascivious appetites and the father of dozens of tieflings—and, at the same time, his family is a source of great pride to him. They are the foundation of an empire, and his brood is loyal and as ambitious as their father. They serve him ably in distant corners of the world, where he sends them to forge alliances through marriages or arcane trades.

entries.name: A Bound Legend
entries: He remains a figure of legend as well as a political force. An expert demon binder, his power is terrifying even at a distance. But wielding worldly power and extending his influence is merely an entertaining game for him. His real goal is to reach immortality—although first he must break the pacts binding him to his dark manor.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The master of demon mountain is a 20th-level spellcaster. Its spellcasting ability is Intelligence (spell save {@dc 20}, {@hit 12} to hit with spell attacks). The master of demon mountain has the following wizard spells prepared:

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (3/Day)
entries: If the Master fails a saving throw, he can choose to succeed instead.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The Master has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Master of Fiends
entries: Fiends summoned by the Master's Summon Fiend share a telepathic link with him, are under his control, and can't summon other demons or devils. A fiend remains until it or the Master dies or until the Master dismisses it as a bonus action. The total CR of the fiends under the Master's control can't exceed 16, otherwise the Master can summon any number or combination of fiends. Any fiends the Master attempts to summon in excess of this limit aren't summoned.

action.name: Master's Knife
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 10} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}11 ({@damage 2d6 + 4}) slashing damage plus 14 ({@damage 4d6}) fire damage.

action.name: Summon Fiend {@recharge 6}
entries: The Master summons {@dice 2d4} {@creature wind demon|ccodex|wind demons} (see page 93), {@dice 1d4} {@creature wind's harp|ccodex|wind's harp devils} (see page 105), {@dice 1d2} {@creature vrock|mm|vrocks}, {@dice 1d2} {@creature chain devil|mm|chain devils}, or 1 {@creature fulad-zereh|ccodex} (see page 85) with no chance of failure. A summoned fiend appears in an unoccupied space within 60 feet of the Master and acts immediately and on the Master's initiative.

legendary.name: Detect
entries: The Master makes a Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check.

legendary.name: Teleport (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: The Master magically teleports, along with any equipment he is wearing or carrying, up to 120 feet to an unoccupied space he can see.

legendary.name: Cast a Spell (Costs 3 Actions)
entries: The Master casts a spell from his list of prepared spells, using a spell slot as normal.

{@i With a dark beard and fiery eyes, the master of Demon Mountain has long been a figure of terror to those who live within sight of his castle. Some say he is the dark, twisted son of Baba Yaga and an unnamed lord of the Abyss. Demons, certainly, bow and speak politely to him, and the least of them jump to his command.}

entries.name: Father of Fiends
entries: The Master of Demon Mountain is a creature of lascivious appetites and the father of dozens of tieflings—and, at the same time, his family is a source of great pride to him. They are the foundation of an empire, and his brood is loyal and as ambitious as their father. They serve him ably in distant corners of the world, where he sends them to forge alliances through marriages or arcane trades.

entries.name: A Bound Legend
entries: He remains a figure of legend as well as a political force. An expert demon binder, his power is terrifying even at a distance. But wielding worldly power and extending his influence is merely an entertaining game for him. His real goal is to reach immortality—although first he must break the pacts binding him to his dark manor.

entries.name: The Master of Demon Mountain in Midgard
entries: Hundreds of years ago, the Archmage of Vael Turog escaped the destruction his nation suffered in the Mage Wars and made his way far to the east, where he found a mountain at the site of the conjunction of two powerful ley lines. Located on the southern border of the tsar of Vidim's lands, this mountain was filled with dark and demonic energies and had been considered a blight on the map in the tsar's estimation. The archmage was offered dominion over the mountain if he could tame it and end the threats that issued from it. He summoned and bound a demonic legion, brought the mountain under his control, and staked his claim. The tsar, unaware and uninterested in the details, was delighted, and the archmage became known as the Master of Demon Mountain.

He raised a castle there overnight, called Castle Dontrona, and there he has ruled for so long that the people of the surrounding plains have largely forgotten his name. Out of fear or dread of drawing his attention, they refer to him as "the Master" when occasion demands they speak of him at all.

Since coming to the mountain, the Master's spells and incantations carry greater potency. The demons praise him, and he has mated with more than a few. The pacts the Master swore to gain power over the mountain and its creatures, however, are not the endless font of power that he had hoped. Indeed, he rarely leaves the mountain, and his children suspect he does not truly command it. Instead, the mountain commands him to bring it reagents and perform certain rituals, as demanded by demonic messengers, dreams, or priests of Chernobog.

His lust for power drives him to ally with the Bemmeans, to offer arcana to the Dragon Empire, and to seek the hand of the tsar's comely daughters. His depravity simmers beneath an affected veneer of civility. In distant courts, the Master is known by the name he used in Vael Turog: Roggero Lucar Ordontrona, or sometimes an even older name, Gardever the Archmage of Vael Turog. He claims to be the last living scion of the noble bloodline of Vael Turog. Whether true or an empty boast, he acts the part and then some.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The master of demon mountain is a 20th-level spellcaster. Its spellcasting ability is Intelligence (spell save {@dc 20}, {@hit 12} to hit with spell attacks). The master of demon mountain has the following wizard spells prepared:

spells: {@footnote {@i land bond}|The {@i Midgard World Handbook} by Kobold Press is currently unconverted for 5eTools.}
{@footnote {@i ley disruption}|The {@i Midgard World Handbook} by Kobold Press is currently unconverted for 5eTools.}
{@footnote {@i ley energy bolt}|The {@i Midgard World Handbook} by Kobold Press is currently unconverted for 5eTools.}
{@footnote {@i ley sense}|The {@i Midgard World Handbook} by Kobold Press is currently unconverted for 5eTools.}
{@footnote {@i ray of life suppression}|The {@i Midgard World Handbook} by Kobold Press is currently unconverted for 5eTools.}
{@footnote {@i ley leech}|The {@i Midgard World Handbook} by Kobold Press is currently unconverted for 5eTools.}
{@footnote {@i ley whip}|The {@i Midgard World Handbook} by Kobold Press is currently unconverted for 5eTools.}
{@footnote {@i disruptive aura}|The {@i Midgard World Handbook} by Kobold Press is currently unconverted for 5eTools.}
{@footnote {@i ley storm}|The {@i Midgard World Handbook} by Kobold Press is currently unconverted for 5eTools.}
{@footnote {@i ley surge}|The {@i Midgard World Handbook} by Kobold Press is currently unconverted for 5eTools.}

trait.name: Metal Sense
entries: The megapede can sense any metal within 600 feet of it. It knows the direction to the metal and can identify the specific type of metal within the area.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The megapede makes one stinger attack and one bite attack. It can use its Consume Metal in place of its bite attack.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}10 ({@damage 2d6 + 3}) slashing damage plus 3 ({@damage 1d6}) acid damage. If the target is a Large or smaller creature, it is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 13}). Until this grapple ends, the megapede has advantage on attacks against the {@condition grappled} target, and it can't make bite attacks against another target.

action.name: Stinger
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}8 ({@damage 1d10 + 3}) piercing damage and the target must make a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw or become {@condition poisoned} for 1 minute.

action.name: Consume Metal
entries: The megapede consumes one unattended Medium or smaller metal object or attempts to consume a metal object worn or held by the creature it is grappling. The {@condition grappled} creature must succeed on a {@dc 13} Strength saving throw or the object is consumed. If the object is a magic item, the creature has advantage on the saving throw. Magic items consumed by the megapede stay intact in its stomach for {@dice 1d4} hours before they are destroyed.

action.name: Acid Spray {@recharge 6}
entries: The megapede spits acid in a line that is 30 feet long and 5 feet wide, provided that it has no creature {@condition grappled}. Each creature in that line must make a {@dc 13} Dexterity saving throw, taking 18 ({@damage 4d8}) acid damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.
{@i A massive centipede lifts the upper half of its body off the ground, legs thrashing. Acid drips from hungry mandibles stained with liquid metal.}
Megapedes are fifteen-foot-long insects that roam underground areas in search of ore to devour. They are particularly fond of softer precious metals.

entries.name: Mine Destroyers
entries: Megapedes invade active mines, forcing miners to retreat from their acid-spitting mouths. Ousting an invading megapede becomes a top priority, since the insect eats every vein of ore available. Dwarves train special squads that wear hide armor and wield glass weapons to fight the beasts.

entries.name: Taste for Gold
entries: Megapedes prefer the taste of copper, silver, gold, and platinum to other metals. If a morsel of such a metal is nearby, the insect tastes it in the air and abandons all other meals until it can find and consume the treat. Adventurers venturing into megapede lairs should be careful what they carry.

trait.name: Charge
entries: If the labyrinth keeper moves at least 10 feet straight toward a target and then hits it with a gore attack on the same turn, the target takes an extra 9 ({@damage 2d8}) piercing damage. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 15} Strength saving throw or be pushed up to 10 feet away and knocked {@condition prone}.

trait.name: Labyrinthine Recall
entries: The minotaur labyrinth keeper can perfectly recall any path it has traveled.

trait.name: Reckless Caster
entries: At the start of its turn, the minotaur labyrinth keeper can gain advantage on all spell attack rolls it makes during that turn, but attack rolls against it have advantage until the start of its next turn.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The minotaur labyrinth keeper makes two attacks. one with its gore and one with its shortsword.

action.name: Gore
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}13 ({@damage 2d8 + 4}) piercing damage.

action.name: Shortsword
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}11 ({@damage 2d6 + 4}) piercing damage.

{@i The minotaur moon priestess stands at the center of the maze, raising her silver axe to the skies as the lunar light glistens off her silver horns. Behind her, the labyrinth keeper's hands and eyes begin to glow.}

entries.name: The Maze Keepers
entries: The minotaur labyrinth keepers create and restore the maze-lair of their clan. The keeper takes careful notes, studies those who breach its creations, and, when necessary, defends the maze with its clan-mates.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The labyrinth keeper's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 14}, {@hit 6} to hit with spell attacks). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

trait.name: Charge
entries: If the moon priestess moves at least 10 feet straight toward a target and then hits it with a gore attack on the same turn, the target takes an extra 9 ({@damage 2d8}) piercing damage. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 15} Strength saving throw or be pushed up to 10 feet away and knocked {@condition prone}.

trait.name: Labyrinthine Recall
entries: The minotaur moon priestess can perfectly recall any path it has traveled.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The moon priestess makes two melee attacks.

action.name: Labrys Axe
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}17 ({@damage 2d12 + 4}) slashing damage.

action.name: Gore
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}13 ({@damage 2d8 + 4}) piercing damage.

{@i The minotaur moon priestess stands at the center of the maze, raising her silver axe to the skies as the lunar light glistens off her silver horns. Behind her, the labyrinth keeper's hands and eyes begin to glow.}

entries.name: The Moon Worshippers
entries: The moon is a symbol of trickery and confusion, and the minotaur moon priestess heeds the call to worship. She curses those who breach the central chamber of the labyrinth, making sure they never escape.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The moon priestess is a 10th-level spellcaster. Its spellcasting ability is Wisdom (spell save {@dc 14}, {@hit 6} to hit with spell attacks). The moon priestess has the following cleric spells prepared:

monster.name: Lost Minotaur
languages: Understands the languages it knew in life but can't speak

trait.name: Charge
entries: If the lost minotaur moves at least 10 feet straight toward a target and then hits it with a gore attack on the same turn, the target takes an extra 13 ({@damage 3d8}) piercing damage. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 16} Strength saving throw or be pushed up to 10 feet away and knocked {@condition prone}.

trait.name: Keen Smell
entries: The lost minotaur has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on smell.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The lost minotaur has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Sense Life
entries: The lost minotaur can magically sense the presence of living creatures within 1 mile away. It knows each creature's general direction but not exact location.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The minotaur makes two twilight greataxe attacks.

action.name: Twilight Greataxe
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}18 ({@damage 2d12 + 5}) slashing damage and 9 ({@damage 2d8}) necrotic damage.

action.name: Gore
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}14 ({@damage 2d8 + 5}) piercing damage.
{@i The risen corpses of minotaurs who died while trapped in a labyrinth of any kind, lost minotaurs embody the anguish, rage, and humiliation of the worst deaths their people can imagine.}

entries.name: Pliable Malevolence
entries: Motivated by an indiscriminate malice punctuated with a relentless hatred for any who survive an encounter with them, lost minotaurs may be swayed to track and kill specific prey. What it might desire in trade varies from creature to creature, but the prize usually involves an arranged hunt of some kind.

entries.name: Tales of Caution
entries: Among minotaur communities, parents tell their children bloodcurdling tales of lost minotaurs to dissuade them from wandering into old, structurally unsound labyrinths. Tales of the nigh-unstoppable malice of these horrors find an audience most everywhere.

entries.name: Undead Nature
entries: A lost minotaur doesn't require air, food, drink, or sleep.

entries.name: Lost Minotaurs in Midgard
entries: A large number of lost minotaurs came into being after being trapped within their fortified labyrinths and then slowly starved out or slain by gas and necrotic attacks during the Mharoti invasions of minotaur lands three centuries past. Among the minotaur diaspora on the isle of Kyprion and elsewhere, tales of lost minotaurs within the Great Labyrinth in the ruins of Roshgazi abound. Similar tales are told of the old labyrinth of Cindass, though to a lesser degree. Intrepid treasure-seekers in these crumbled places of old magic often fall to the axes of the lost minotaurs.

trait.name: Invisibility
entries: The moon nymph is {@condition invisible} in darkness or in bright light. It can only be seen via normal means when in dim light.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The moon nymph has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The moon nymph makes two beguiling touch attacks or two moonbeam attacks.

action.name: Beguiling Touch
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}17 ({@damage 4d6 + 3}) psychic damage, and the target must succeed on a {@dc 14} Charisma saving throw or be {@condition stunned} until the end of its next turn.

action.name: Moonbeam
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 6} to hit, range 120 ft., one target. {@h}21 ({@damage 4d8 + 3}) radiant damage, and the target is {@condition blinded} until the end of its next turn.

action.name: Veil of Nightmares (1/Day)
entries: The moon nymph emits a wave of hallucinatory nightmare visions. Each creature within 5 feet of the moon nymph must make a {@dc 14} Wisdom saving throw. On a failure, the creature takes 36 ({@damage 8d8}) psychic damage and is {@condition frightened}. On a success, the creature takes half of the damage and isn't {@condition frightened}. A {@condition frightened} creature must succeed on a {@dc 10} Wisdom saving throw at the end of its turn to end the effect on itself. On a second failed save, the creature is {@condition incapacitated} by fright for 1 round. On the start of its next turn, the creature must succeed on a {@dc 12} Wisdom saving throw or be reduced to 0 hp.

{@i Within the moonlight spilling through the window, a shadow coalesces into a lovely female form. Although the figure's body is wraith-like, the face is distinct. A dark smile plays across fine lips, while her eyes sparkle like cold diamonds.}

entries.name: Children of the Night
entries: The passages and fissures between the mortal world and the realms beyond are many and diverse. One such bridge is enabled by the moons of the mortal realm. Moon nymphs, as they are called, use those portals to move into the world, traveling down moonbeams to haunt mortals' dreams.

entries.name: Daughters of the Moon
entries: Those who observe a moon nymph and live to tell the tale describe a slight humanoid creature, wraithlike in form but with a countenance as beautiful as the most alluring fairy. In reality, moon nymphs are genderless, taking on a visage that matches the dreams of their victims. Some might see a beautiful elf, others a handsome dwarf, and lovers of animals might even see a sleek feline or an adorable canine.

Regardless of the form, the moon nymph appears in muted colors, mostly shadowy blacks or pale whites and yellows. Their bodies are often hazy and ghostly at the edges, but the facial features are clearly defined and mesmerizing.

entries.name: Waxing and Waning
entries: The moon nymph's connection to the moon affects its power as the cycles of the moon progress. The statistics given represent a moon nymph during a crescent or gibbous moon. During full moons, the challenge rating increases by 1, the creature's hp maximum increases by 30, it has advantage on attack rolls, and all saving throw DCs increase by 1. Inversely, during new moons, the challenge rating decreases by 1 as the numbers move in the opposite direction.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The morko has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

action.name: Spear
entries: {@atk mw,rw} {@hit 3} to hit, reach 5 ft. and range 20/60 ft., one target. {@h}4 ({@damage 1d6 + 1}) piercing damage, or 5 ({@damage 1d8 + 1}) piercing damage if used with two hands to make a melee attack.

action.name: Disdainful Eye {@recharge 6}
entries: The morko fixes its gaze on a creature it can see within 30 feet. The target must make a {@dc 13} Wisdom saving throw or become cursed with ill manners, taking disadvantage on all ability checks and saving throws based on Charisma. The curse lasts until removed by the {@spell remove curse} spell or other magic, or until the creature drinks a pitcher of curdled milk.

action.name: Shrink (Recharges after a Short or Long Rest)
entries: For 1 minute, the morko magically decreases in size, along with anything it is wearing or carrying. While shrunken, the morko is Tiny, halves its damage dice on Strength-based weapon attacks, and makes Strength checks and Strength saving throws with disadvantage. If the morko lacks the room to grow back to its regular size, it attains the maximum size possible in the space available.

{@i The only portion of this small, gnomish-looking creature's face that is visible through its wiry brown hair is a pair of impish eyes, a bulbous nose, and a mouth in a perpetual sneer. The rest of its body is entirely wrapped up in layers of filthy, mismatched fabric.}

entries.name: Freeloading Fiend
entries: A nuisance who can spell disaster when it gets up to its tricks before winter, a morko lives to glut itself on the labors of others while causing as much chaos as it can. It has a particular predilection for eating its fill of chickens and then digging passages into the coop for foxes and the like. It also delights in unraveling rope and tying the tails of horses and cattle to whatever will cause the most destruction when it shouts in the animal's ear.

entries.name: Loves a Good Fire
entries: Morkos can't be harmed by fire, but they do enjoy a warm place to sleep. This combination led them to discover the best place for sleep: about halfway down a chimney. The creatures wriggle down and wedge themselves in, nice and cozy, occasionally poking down at the embers with their spears to get the flames going nice and hot. The shouts and curses of those below as the building begins to fill with smoke makes the practice that much more enjoyable.

entries.name: Withering Looks
entries: Morkos derive a great deal of enjoyment from lurking on the outskirts of villages prior to any festival which involves dancing, and they have an excellent memory for such dates. They hide and wait until a lone individual comes close to their location, whereupon they reveal themselves and give the hapless victim a withering stare before scampering off into the wilds. The recipient of this gaze suffers under a particularly cruel curse, and the morko will likely hide somewhere to watch the effects unfold during the festivities.

trait.name: Immutable Form
entries: The mytholabe is immune to any spell or effect that would alter its form.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The mytholabe has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Magic Weapons
entries: The mytholabe's weapon attacks are magical.

trait.name: Melodious Recharge
entries: Whenever the mytholabe is hit by a magical weapon attack, it recharges its Purifying Resonance ability.

trait.name: Spanner In the Works
entries: When the mytholabe suffers a critical hit from a nonmagical weapon, the attacker quadruples the dice rolled instead of doubling them.

trait.name: Sentient Transformation
entries: If the mytholabe is inhabited by a sentient weapon, its mental statistics and alignment change to match that of the weapon's.

trait.name: Unbearable Scraping
entries: When the mytholabe is hit with a nonmagical melee weapon attack, each creature within 15 feet of it must succeed on a {@dc 16} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition deafened} for 1 minute.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The mytholabe makes three heroic jab attacks. When its Purifying Resonance is available, it can use the resonance in place of one heroic jab attack.

action.name: Heroic Jab
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 9} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}9 ({@damage 1d8 + 5}) piercing damage plus 7 ({@damage 2d6}) radiant damage.

action.name: Purifying Resonance {@recharge 5}
entries: The mytholabe thrums with a harmonic resonance that brings order to those within 30 feet. Each creature in that area must succeed on a {@dc 16} Constitution saving throw or have all conditions and magical effects on it ended immediately and any concentration it's maintaining broken.
{@i An ever-shifting clockwork wonder engineered by the divine floats a few feet off the ground, bearing the weapons of legends long past.}

When heroes die, their magic equipment is often buried with them or passed to their descendents, but sometimes the gods have other plans for such items. The gods will bind the personal effects of their many fallen champions into clockwork mechanisms that do their bidding.

entries.name: Impervious
entries: Crafted from the finest, toughest materials, and resonating with divine power that emits a deep, beautiful thrum, it is virtually impossible to damage a mytholabe through conventional heroic means. Magic weapons clang harmoniously off it with no lasting impact, and magical effects fare only slightly better.

entries.name: Weakness to the mundane
entries: Mytholabes are broken, not killed. A common spear thrust into a gear will mar the perfection of its mechanical workings and its harmonic resonance. Mundane weapons are the most effective, but the nails-on-chalkboard screeching during the dismantling process must be painfully endured.

entries.name: Housing for sentience
entries: Sometimes a sentient weapon is part of the machine, and its personality takes over (or corrupts) it. Some weapons find this pleasing; others, suffocating.

entries.name: Construct Nature
entries: mytholabe doesn't require air, food, drink, or sleep.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The mytholabe's innate spellcasting ability is Wisdom (spell save {@dc 0}). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

monster.name: Nachzehrer
languages: The languages it knew in life

trait.name: Grave Pox
entries: A creature infected with grave pox becomes vulnerable to necrotic damage and gains one level of {@condition exhaustion} that can't be removed until the disease is cured. Additionally, the creature cannot reduce its {@condition exhaustion} by finishing a long rest. The infected creature is highly contagious. Each creature that touches it, or that is within 10 feet of it when it finishes a long rest, must succeed on a {@dc 12} Constitution saving throw or also contract grave pox.

When an infected creature finishes a long rest, it must succeed on a {@dc 16} Constitution saving throw or gain one level of {@condition exhaustion}. As the disease progresses, the infected creature becomes weaker and develops painful green pustules all over its skin. A creature that succeeds on two saving throws against the disease recovers from it. The cured creature is no longer vulnerable to necrotic damage and can remove {@condition exhaustion} levels as normal.

trait.name: Weakening Shadow
entries: A creature other than a construct or undead has disadvantage on attack rolls, saving throws, and ability checks based on Strength while within 5 feet of the nachzehrer.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The nachzehrer makes three attacks. two with its fists and one with its bite.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d4 + 5}) piercing damage plus 13 ({@damage 3d8}) necrotic damage. The target's hp maximum is reduced by an amount equal to the necrotic damage taken, and the nachzehrer regains hp equal to that amount. The reduction lasts until the target finishes a long rest. The target dies if this effect reduces its hp maximum to 0. The target must succeed on a {@dc 16} Constitution saving throw or become infected with the grave pox disease (see the Grave Pox trait).

action.name: Fist
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}12 ({@damage 2d6 + 5}) bludgeoning damage.
{@i This walking corpse's skin is tight against its bones and covered in weeping pustules. Its burial clothes are shredded and tattered at the cuffs and sleeves.}

Nachzehrer are undead superficially similar to ghouls and easily mistaken for them at a distance. The giveaway is the multitude of sores and pustules that dot the creature's skin, ready to burst with virulent fluids.

entries.name: Plague Born
entries: Nachzehrer arise when plague strikes and kills a large number of people. The first victim of a plague might rise as one of these foul undead, and if that nachzehrer can infect enough victims a second nachzehrer will rise to join the first.

entries.name: Feeds on Life
entries: Nachzehrer are driven to feed on the essence of the living. The creature's shadow has a draining effect on living creatures, sapping their strength when it falls across them and leaving them ripe for the nachzehrer's grisly feeding. The creature's grinding teeth drain the life from its victims, while spreading its disease into the victim. Nachzehrer are particularly driven to hunt down and consume their own living family members.

entries.name: Undead Nature
entries: A nachzehrer doesn't require air, food, drink, or sleep.

trait.name: Rejuvenation
entries: If it dies, the moonchild naga returns to life in {@dice 1d6} days and regains all its hp. Only a {@spell wish} spell can prevent this trait from functioning.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}13 ({@damage 2d8 + 4}) piercing damage plus 18 ({@damage 4d8}) poison damage.

action.name: Constrict
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}11 ({@damage 2d6 + 4}) bludgeoning damage, and the target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 14}). Until this grapple ends, the target is {@condition restrained}, and the naga can't constrict another target.

action.name: Starry Gaze
entries: The moonchild naga's bottomless gaze inexorably draws the eye of one target within 30 feet. If the target can see the naga, it must succeed on a {@dc 15} Wisdom saving throw or be {@condition stunned} until the end of the naga's next turn. If the target's saving throw is successful, it is immune to the naga's gaze for the next 24 hours.
{@i This great serpent with shimmering scales of varying colors has the face of a beautiful woman. Its eyes shine like the moon in a sea of stars, and it sways to an unheard rhythm.}

entries.name: Starry Gaze
entries: The pupils and irises of a moonchild naga appear as moons in miniature, surrounded by black sclera dotted with faintly glowing stars. The moonchild naga uses its eyes to claim a connection to the powers of the moon and the stars, which grants it powers of prophecy. The bewitching power in their gaze lends some credence to these claims.

entries.name: Manipulative Masters
entries: These nagas excel at manipulation, convincing those who listen of their own hidden greatness, and that, through time spent in communion and service to the naga, they can unlock their true potential. Through ritual deprivation, drug-induced visions, the promised revelation of great secrets that never come, and the reinforcement of the naga's own place in their lives, moonchild nagas never lack for a small cadre of underlings to do their bidding.

entries.name: Two is a Crowd
entries: Moonchild nagas avoid one another for fear that another will spoil their efforts or expose them as charlatans in order to make off with their devotees.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The moonchild naga's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 15}, {@hit 7} to hit with spell attacks). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring only verbal components:

trait.name: Shadow Stealth
entries: While in dim light or darkness, the nalusa falaya can take the {@action Hide} action as a bonus action.

trait.name: Shadow Step
entries: As an action, the nalusa falaya can teleport itself to a shadow it can see within 30 feet.

trait.name: Sunlight Weakness
entries: While in sunlight, the nalusa falaya has disadvantage on ability checks, attack rolls, and saving throws.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d6 + 2}) piercing damage. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 12} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d8 + 2}) slashing damage.

action.name: Terrifying Glare
entries: The nalusa falaya targets one creature it can see within 30 feet of it. If the target can see the nalusa falaya, the target must succeed on a {@dc 12} Wisdom saving throw or be {@condition frightened} until the end of the nalusa falaya's next turn.

{@i A tall, spindly humanoid covered in dark fur lumbers forward. Its lupine skull hosts pointed ears ending in tufts of fur and small, black eyes, which glow with reflected light. Sharp spines protrude from its hunched back.}

Primarily living alone, the nalusa falaya seem to mutter to themselves for company. In a few cases, they ally themselves with {@creature zoog|ccodex|zoogs} or spiders and may refer to these creatures as their "children."

entries.name: Unsavory Appetites
entries: The nalusa falaya's jaw hosts terrifying teeth, and its eyes gleam in even the dimmest light. Humanoid young are their favorite delicacy, and many nalusa falaya have a particular appetite for elven young.

entries.name: Shadow Walkers
entries: While this evil and devious creature may walk as a humanoid, its form has been seen to slither like a snake from shadow to shadow, where it disappears from sight. It is rumored that these creatures were once mortals but have been corrupted by energies from the Void.

entries.name: Portal Wardens
entries: The nalusa falaya are often drawn to portals leading to or from planes of shadow, death, and darkness. These portals may resemble dark ponds, shadowy wells full of peculiar echoes, or even dark caverns covered in spiraling runes. When losing a battle, they sometimes disappear into shadow and never return.

trait.name: Necrotic Regeneration
entries: While attached to a living host, a necrotic tick leaks negative energy into the host's bloodstream, quickly closing over the creature's wounds with scabrous, necrotic flesh. If the host doesn't already have regeneration, it regains 2 hp at the start of its turn if it has at least 1 hit point.

Track how many "necrotic hp" a host recovers via Necrotic Regeneration. Magical healing reverses the necrosis and subtracts an equal number of necrotic hp from those accumulated. When the necrotic hp equal the host's hit point maximum, the host becomes a zombie.

trait.name: Ride Host
entries: When a necrotic tick's living host has lost three-quarters of its maximum hp from Blood Drain, the tick's toxins fill the host with an unnatural desire to approach other living beings. When a suitable creature is within 5 feet, the tick incites a sudden rage in the host, riding the current host to a new host. The current host must succeed on a {@dc 13} Wisdom saving throw or it attempts to grapple a living creature within 5 feet of it as a reaction. The host can re-attempt this saving throw at the end of each turn that it suffers damage from the necrotic tick's Blood Drain.

action.name: Blood Drain
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. {@h}1 piercing damage, and the tick attaches to the target. While attached, the necrotic tick doesn't attack. Instead, at the start of each of the tick's turns, the target loses 5 ({@dice 1d4 + 3}) hp due to blood loss. The target must make a {@dc 13} Wisdom saving throw. If it fails, it is affected by the tick's toxins and doesn't attempt to remove the tick. The host will even replace a dislodged tick unless prevented from doing so for 1 minute, after which the tick's influence fades.

The tick can detach itself by spending 5 feet of its movement. It does so when seeking a new host or if the target dies. A creature, including the target, can use its action to detach the tick. When a necrotic tick detaches, voluntarily or otherwise, its host takes 1 necrotic damage.
{@i A tick, bloated to the size of a child's head, buries its mandibles deep in its victim. Circles of necrotic flesh bubble around the wound.}

entries.name: Zombie Hosts
entries: Necrotic ticks are normal ticks that have gorged themselves on blood rich with necrotic energy. They grow unnaturally large as they feed, weighing in excess of four pounds when fully engorged. Most begin their voracious lives attached to the backs of animal zombies, and it is not uncommon to find a cluster of them on a single animal.

entries.name: Death Bite
entries: When the blood of a necrotic tick's undead host runs dry, the parasite rides its victim to a new host—usually an unfortunate living creature. As it sucks the living creature's blood, it leaks necrotic energy into the bite wound and starts a process that slowly turns the hapless victim into a zombie one pound of flesh at a time. If no potential hosts are available, ridden hosts hide in dark crevices or in trees, where they wait to pounce on the next passerby and deliver their crawling passengers.

trait.name: Hold Breath
entries: The nian can hold its breath for 30 minutes.

trait.name: Trampling Charge
entries: If the nian moves at least 20 feet straight toward a creature and then hits it with a gore attack on the same turn, that target must succeed on a {@dc 14} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}. If the target is {@condition prone}, the nian can make one stomp attack against it as a bonus action.

trait.name: Tremulous
entries: The nian is inherently fearful of loud noises, fire, and the color red. It will not choose to move toward any red object or any fiery or burning materials. If presented forcefully with a red object, flame, or if it is dealt fire or thunder damage, the nian must succeed on a {@dc 13} Wisdom saving throw or become {@condition frightened} until the end of its next turn. After it has been {@condition frightened} by a specific red object or a particular source of noise (such as clanging a weapon on a shield) or fire (such as the burning hands spell), the nian can't be {@condition frightened} by that same source again for 24 hours.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}17 ({@damage 2d12 + 4}) piercing damage.

action.name: Gore
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}13 ({@damage 2d8 + 4}) piercing damage.

action.name: Stomp
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one {@condition prone} creature. {@h}15 ({@damage 2d10 + 4}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Year's Termination (1/Day)
entries: The nian creates magical darkness and silence around it in a 15-foot-radius sphere that moves with it and spreads around corners. The dark silence lasts as long as the nian maintains concentration, up to 10 minutes (as if concentrating on a spell). The nian sees objects in the sphere in shades of gray. Darkvision can't penetrate the darkness, no natural light can illuminate it, no sound can be created within or pass through it, and any creature or object entirely inside the sphere of dark silence is immune to thunder damage. Creatures entirely inside the darkness are {@condition deafened} and can't cast spells that include a verbal component. If any of the darkness overlaps with an area of light created by a spell of 2nd level or lower, the spell creating the light is destroyed.
{@i The creature has the body of a massive, powerful bull and the head of a sleek and majestic lion with a single curved horn rising from its skull.}

entries.name: Divine Punishment
entries: It is said that nian are sent by the gods to punish villages that have fallen out of favor or committed some terrible crime. Others believe that nian simply come to take food and riches that are not theirs, hoarding their treasures in underwater grottos or mountainous caverns.

entries.name: Sign of Beginnings and Endings
entries: nian regularly hibernates for months, preferring to hunt during times when the seasons are shifting. Because of this, many villages in the east use a nian's appearance as a signal of changing times. The celebrations that take place during times of change in these villages, such as harvest festivals or new year gatherings, include many of the objects that ward against nians: red decorations, fiery displays, and clanging instruments.

trait.name: Flyby
entries: The nightgaunt doesn't provoke an opportunity attack when it flies out of an enemy's reach.

trait.name: Pack Tactics
entries: The nightgaunt has advantage on attack rolls against a creature if at least one of the nightgaunt's allies is within 5 feet of the creature and the ally isn't {@condition incapacitated}.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The nightgaunt has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Utterly Silent
entries: The nightgaunt doesn't make a sound and has advantage on Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) checks.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The nightgaunt can use its Baneful Presence. It then makes three attacks. two with its clutching claws and one with its barbed tail. If the nightgaunt is grappling a creature, it can use its barbed tail one additional time.

action.name: Clutching Claws
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}13 ({@damage 2d8 + 4}) slashing damage, and the target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 16}) if it is a Medium or smaller creature. Until this grapple ends, the target is {@condition restrained}. The nightgaunt has two claws, each of which can grapple only one target. While using a claw to grapple, the nightgaunt can't use that claw to attack.

action.name: Barbed Tail
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}8 ({@damage 1d8 + 4}) piercing damage plus 10 ({@damage 3d6}) poison damage.

action.name: Baneful Presence
entries: Each creature of the nightgaunt's choice that is within 30 feet of the nightgaunt and aware of it must succeed on a {@dc 16} Wisdom saving throw or have disadvantage on all attack rolls and saving throws for 1 minute. A creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success. If a creature's saving throw is successful or the effect ends for it, the creature is immune to the nightgaunt's Baneful Presence for the next 24 hours.

{@i The terrible outline of something noxiously thin and bat-winged descends silently from above—a faceless black being with smooth, whale-like skin and horns that curve toward each other. Its barbed tail lashes needlessly as it clutches the air with ugly prehensile paws.}

entries.name: Silent Malevolence
entries: Nightgaunts never speak or smile, having only a suggestive blankness where a face ought to be. The beating of a nightgaunt's membranous wings makes no sound; nor does the tickling grasp of its cold, rubbery paws.

entries.name: Nightmare Servitors
entries: These mindless aberrations are creations of an elder god of the Great Abyss, who wages inter‑dimensional war with various gods and horrors of the Outer Void. Nightgaunts serve as the advance guard and battle steeds of the ghouls that inhabit the darkest corners of the Shadow Realm and realms of pure dream and fancy. On occasion, they ally themselves with humans and the forces of light against greater chaos and particularly hated demon lords. Such alliances last only so long as is necessary to restore the rule of law and burn out all corruption from a place. Once this is accomplished, they sometimes leave, satisfied in their work, and other times remain to attack the wounded forces of good.

entries.name: Void Traveler
entries: The nightgaunt doesn't require air, food, drink, or ambient pressure.

trait.name: Aquatic
entries: The ningyo can breathe only underwater and can hold its breath for 1 hour.

trait.name: Curse of Ill Fortune
entries: When a creature that the ningyo can see attacks the ningyo and misses, the attack is automatically redirected against another creature within 5 feet of the ningyo or the attacker. This attack uses the same attack roll.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The ningyo makes four barbed tentacle attacks.

action.name: Barbed Tentacle
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}8 ({@damage 1d6 + 5}) piercing damage plus 5 ({@damage 1d10}) poison damage.

reaction.name: Share Pain
